While it may not be true to our CI setup but is quite common for doc building to not run under tox (readthedocs does this).

For example I am currently using tox v4 and building docs with it will fail due to missing tox executable (it is called tox4 until it is released). Even after it is released `tox -va` will not longer work, as it would become `tox list`.

zuul/zk/event_queues.py.message:
Do we want to have this backward compatible with the current version?

    event = model.ConnectionEvent.fromDict(data.get('event_data', data))

We might have unprocessed connection events in ZK with the old format that would otherwise lead to a KeyError.
Good idea.  We moved the other queues, but not this one.

We don't shard on the event path, only on the data path.  sharding.BufferedShardWriter is what actually implements the sharding, on line 262.

The event_path is a sequence because the event queue is composed of sequential znodes (ie, the sequence number provides the queue ordering of the event).
Why bother with sharding on the event_path if we intend to always have a single sequence node?
Yup I see that now. I conflated sequences and sharding. They use a similar underlying implementation but the specific details for each are important here. The behavior is completely different.
Because this is sharded and that is not.

Why does this use the more complicated create on the root then stream the data to the path instead of what appears to be the simpler alternative below of creating the data_path and setting sequence to True?

From an order of operations perspective I think it might be more correct to delete the side_channel_path first. Then if we have any errors the event will hang around allowing us to try removal again later?

Also if you get NoNodeError when deleting the side_channel_path I think you want to continue to try and delete the event itself. I believe this is why you have the current order, but I don't think the current order would handle other errors (like connection errors?) properly.
Yeah, I think we can switch it around, but it'll be more verbose.
In this case I think the verbosity is worthwhile to make this more robust to the various errors that may occur.
Is this meant to be encoded_data?
Yes, our size limit is based on the amount of data we're going to store in zk, so this makes the decision about sharding based on what it's about to store.
But still mostly accurate -- in that if we expect data and it's not there, it's corrupt.  I'll rephrase.
This comment is no longer completely accurate.
Copy-pasta error: this shouldn't say 'tenant specific'

Thanks your review, I made wrong submit contents to this US. Now Mark clarified this and I updated in this version. Your above good comments are also applied in this dockerfile.

Do we really need additional layers that each of these individual calls to RUN will create? If not I would rather see them consolidated into one RUN in order to minimise unneeded layers, ie.

RUN    apt-get update && apt-get install -y \
￼           build-essential \
￼           live-build \
￼           pbuilder \
 ￼          debootstrap \
           ...
           emacs && \
       pip3 install Flask && \
       sbuild-adduser root && \
       ...
Replaced the package builder's dockerfile with stx builder's. thanks.

This type of thing being included in the Dockerfile is going to prevent a single reusable container from being made available to all developers on Dockerhub. We are essentially back to having each developer building their own 'version' of the container. This is not viable and goes against what was proposed in the Spec. What are the plans to get us away from this?

I second this.  The end goal is a reusable container, which requires the external user ids are not imported into the docker image.  We can't publish a non-reusable container to dockerhub.

That said, there is value in allowing users to build personal use stx-builder containers to get an early taste of the new debian build system.  I'll give it my +2... but more work is required.

doc/source/specs/stx-6.0/approved/securi.message: Not sure instability is the right word here - how about "Expired certificates prevent the proper operation of the platform"?

Should say

"Example use cases:"

here, as this is not the exhaustive list of use cases to be addressed by this feature.

wording ?
a CertAudit mechnanism to audit the expiry of ...

wording ?

"... actively alarmed certificates in order to detect an updated certificate and clear the alarm more quickly than waiting for the next audit."

I would change this to:

"Cert-mon will scan all cert-manager certificates in all namespaces as part of the audit.

I would change this to:

"... certificates that are not being managed by cert-manager."

I would change this to:

"... for cert-manager certificates and K8S secrets."
We don't typically allow users to configure our system by editing configuration files. Why can't this configuration be stored in the sysinv database (i.e. existing certificate table or a new table)?

Actually the original idea here was that this configuration file was NOT modifiable by user.  I.E. this was just an internal .conf file for holding the hard-coded PEM file locations for the different certificate types configurable via 'system certificate-install ...'.  In theory, should probably just be constants defined in code, as there is no reason why these would change.

But then we probably confused things by later talking about also having the same attributes in this file, that we were proposing as annotations on the CERTIFICATES and SECRETS, i.e. alarmExpiryEnabled, alarmExpiryBefore, alarmExpiryServerity, alarmExpiryText, ... which would be user configurable in the context of annotations on the CERTIFICATES and SECRETS.

Agree that if we wanted to go down this path (i.e. supporting configurability of the alarming for certificates when managed by 'system certificate-install'), then extending the sysinv cert table db would be the way to go.

Was chatting about this with Sabeel, and adding 4-5 new attributes to sysinv cert db table, with restapi, and CLI and testing ... is a bunch of work for a CLI that we are thinking of deprecating in the next next release (i.e. staringx r7-ish).

So we were going to instead propose the following:
- for certificates managed by 'system certificate-install'
     * use constants in code for PEM file locations of the different cert types
       managed by this command
     * always generate alarmExpiry for these certs
     * always use some internal defaults for alarmSeverity, alarmBefore and alarmTExt
     * if user wants to configure the alarming of these certs,
       he must switchover and use the NEW APPROACH to configuring these certificates
           o i.e. configure the K8S CERTIFICATE or SECRET with the appropriate name and
                  with the new annotations for configuring the alarmExpiry details.
           o where cert-mon will install the certificate, and
                   cert-audit will alarm the certificate with customized annotation attributes

Then discuss the old stuff ... i.e. certificates managed outside of both cert-manager certificates and k8s secrets.
e.g. I think you only need to say something like:

For StarlingS Platform certificates that are simply managed in PEM files, the cert-mon service's CertAudit will audit the expiry of these certificates according to their hard-coded absolute filepaths.  These hard-coded filepaths will be managed in an internal configuration file, that will also optionally contain any internal customization of the alarm associated with these certificates.  This will include the 'ssl' (or 'tpm') and 'docker-registry' certificates when user configured via 'system certificate-install --mode <mode> <pemfile>'.  This will also include the k8s root ca certificate.
I don't think we want users editing internal configuration files. Shouldn't this be stored in the database instead?
See other comment for new proposal on this.

Change to:

For certificates managed by cert-manager certificate and/or k8s secret, the alarm raising threshold of N weeks (default=4), alarm severity and/or alarm text can be changed thru annotations on the certificate or secret.  The alarm itself can also be completely disabled thru an annotation as well.
Please update the formatting for all your numbered lists so they appear as separate lines in the generated output.

change to 
"...and their associated K8S TLS Secret)..."

change to?
"... simply being managed by ..."

change to:
"certificates that are actively being alarmed"

As discussed offline ... we need to decide on something different here.

This was really just for the usability of having alarms clear more quickly after user updates a certificate.

OPTION 1: 
Just get rid of this completely and simply say that alarms are SET/CLEARED once a day.

As in a large DC scenario, when AdminEp cert management updates root ca, there will be like 1,000 certs that change very quickly ... and in most cases, there will be no active alarms yet because the certs are being renewed prior to expiry ... but we would be doing a lot of checks for nothing.


OPTION 2:
- 24 hour / daily full audit of ALL certs
- optional 1 hour audit that
     * only runs if there are actively SET alarms on certificates, and
     * only audits certificates associated with alarmed certificates.
     ... in order to clear alarm more quickly.

Thoughts ?
As opposed to golang? I'm not sure that language selection is the most important criteria here.

You can't use the existing cert-mon service. It will impact the existing responsibilities of that service (e.g. syncing updated certificates to subclouds). The existing cert-mon process is already overloaded on systems with 100s of subclouds. At a minimum, you would need to introduce a new cert-audit service into sysinv (similar to the cert-mon service). The other option would be to introduce a new k8s platform application/pod to do this monitoring. I think you need to explore that option and look at how it compares to the proposal of adding a new process to the sysinv component.

Agree that we should not put this in cert-mon if it is already overloaded on large DC systems.

Decoupling the alarming activity into either a new cert-audit sm service or a platform deployment/pod would mean the lower priority alarming activity would not block the cert synchronization work ... and could be configured to run at a lower priority than service affecting platform processes / pods.
I believe this is the right approach - why wasn't it chosen?
See other comment for new proposal on this.

alarm types for expiringSoon and expired certificates

We should specify severity, and give some examples of alarmText and alarmEntityID for the different use cases.
Do we also want to give an example the annotations on certificates or secrets ?

We actually need to consider the impact on controller cpu of the daily full audit of certificates on a large DC system where the SystemController will have over 1,000 certificates.
i.e.
- can we run the cert-audit process at lower priority than other processes ?
- should we intentionally throttle the auditing of certificates in order to avoid large cpu spikes even at low priority ?
Added comment to capture both options. Needs more input from others to explore and pick the right option
Also need to document annotations for customizing certificate alarming behaviour.

Please mention the option to introduce a new k8s platform application/pod to do this monitoring. I think you need to explore that option and look at how it compares to the selected option of adding a new bare metal service.
May want to get rid of the trailing spaces throughout this document.
Avoid using acronym unless the unabbreviated version has been mentioned earlier.
Please indicate which of these alarms are management affecting.
Added a note in the Upgrade section about which certificates will be managementAffecting.

We already have cert-mon that audits and syncs certs to the subclouds. I am unclear of the role of the new service CertAudit. Shouldn't it operate locally and leave subcloud interactions to cert-mon? If so, why would CertAudit use more cpu/memory in large DC?

The cert-mon service syncs the certificates between the central controller and the subclouds, but does not monitor the expiry date (it just raises a out-of-sync alarm in case of syncing issues).

Original proposal on this spec was to implement this feature in cert-mon service, but objection from Bart was that this will slow cert-mon even more, since we are already seeing scalability issues related to cert-mon.
Considering that, we decided to create a separate service to decouple alarm expiry date monitoring from cert-mon into this new service.

Re large DC systems, if for e.g., there are 1000 subclouds, there will be 1000 IntermediateCAs associated with those subclouds (used as part of the secure communication cert chain). This auditing service will have to cycle through all of those certificates and check expiry date in order to raise/clear alarms.
Good comment Tee - why wouldn't we delegate the responsibility for alarming expired certificates to each subcloud (for the certficates specific to that subcloud)?

If the objective is to raise an alarm for expiring/expired certificate then the most scalable solution is to make CertAudit one of the house keeping services (e.g. could be a collectd plugin). CertAudit on the system controller only needs to check cert expiry date for the central cloud and let CertAudits on the subclouds to check theirs.

Subcloud alarms are visible on Horizon and are part of dcmanager alarm summary.
It's not a may, it's a will. Upgrade will not start with an outstanding management affecting alarm.

ADD:

. Kubernetes annotations will also be able to customize some of the alarm settings, see below.

Wording?

Customization of alarms for certificates managed by 'system certificate-install ... <pemfile>' ...
You should maybe move this after line 88 and specify that this will ONLY audit certificates with active alarms.

wording?

... the proposed solution was chosen to use existing Certificate and TLS Secrets in the k8s etcd database, with annotations for customizing the certificate alarming behaviour.

is this a SECRET ?
should add the line

  Kind: Secret

... maybe after namespace

I think you need to re-word this to explain that in order to distribute the auditing and alarming of certificates in a DC system where there can be 1,000s of CERTIFICATES and TLS SECRETS (i.e. one each per subcloud being managed), the cert-alarm audit algorithm will explicitly skip the DcAdminEpInterCa Certificates/Secrets for the subclouds' that are present on the systemController.  These DcAdminEpInterCa Secrets are replicated on the subclouds and will be audited and alarmed on the subcloud.

Reword?

The full certificate alarm audit is run once every 24 hours, and the optional hourly certificate alarm audit only runs when a certificate alarm is active and only audits alarmed certificates.

As mentioned in email, managementAffecting is specified at the alarmID (not when generating an instance of the alarm) ... so you would have to have separate alarmIDs for platform vs user certificate alarms.

I'd suggest just making all certificate alarms ... both expiringSoon and expired ... managementAffecting ... i mean you don't want a certificate to expire in the middle of an upgrade.
sm , if new sm-managed service for 'cert-alarm'

suggest this to be a smaller number. currently the admin endpoint certificate that are managed by cert-manager comes with 30 days renewBefore setting. setting the alarm before to equal number could potentially raise alarms that will be clear in next little while causing unnecessary concern to the admin user.

So the alarm(s) can linger up to 1 hour after the cert has been renewed. This means operations that are affected by management affecting alarms (e.g. upgrade) cannot be performed unless the user also has to manually delete the alarm(s) in one or more regions?

Yes, based on current design proposal, the user will need to wait an hour or workaround (manually delete alarm) to proceed with upgrade. I dont think it makes sense to increase the frequency of checks (to avoid overloading the system) without major design changes.
How about k8s component cert bundle and etcd cert bundle?

Only showing the certificate management under the platform context here. The platform does manage the CA certificate, which is currently done via the 'system certificate-install' command, so that entry covers the use case.
Have you considered the automatic annotation by VIM instead of user's manual operation? From users perspective, they are happy to see their certificates being alarmed by the platform by default.

Not familiar with that plugin, but if users are using some sort of automated system in addition to k8s, they can. The default behavior will be to turn the alarms on, so user can manually intervene if alarms are not needed.

cinder/cmd/volume.py.message:
The order of precedence doesn't look right. I think it should be:

1. getattr(CONF, backend).backend_host
2. getattr(CONF, SHARED_CONF_GROUP).backend_host
3. CONF.host

That way a backend that specifically declares its own backend_host will override the value in backend_defaults.
You are absolutely correct . Thanks for the catch !

I prefer the original L93 (backend_host or CONF.host, backend) because it reinforces the notion that backend_host and CONF.host are conceptually different.

Putting it all together:

    backend_host = (getattr(CONF, backend).backend_host or
                    getattr(CONF, SHARED_CONF_GROUP).backend_host)
    host = "%s@%s" % (backend_host or CONF.host, backend)
That makes sense. Thanks for the suggestion.

We are considering that the user can (but not suggested) manipulate this file in the middle of the procedure, removing or already putting it on the {rootcacertfile}.
The procedure will work successfully even if this happens, because components and pods will already be receiving certificates signed by the new rootca (concatenated in the original ca file in steps before). So my opinion is that if new cert file does not exist at this moment, is not such a problem and the configuration application should just move forward, ignoring this step (as it is now with 'onlyif').

Originally the onlyif is to support re-run trustnewca in case where the class apply fails after the file is removed. But I think we can remove the onlyif for both the certfile and keyfile, and relocate the removal of the three files (rootca_certfile_new, rootca_keyfile_new, rootca_cerfile_old) on line 932-943 to the very end of the class. This way we still support re-run of the class if it fails, but we will capture the error where the files don't exist (and fails the trustnewca operation).

What exactly happens here and when is it called?

This method is not super well thought out at the moment. And its hard for me to say when or if it will be. The current workflow is for the node to periodically attest itself and for the verifier to keep up to date with the state of the node. Keylime offers the ability to do revocation for you and take some kind of action when a node has become invalid. It might be possible to have the verifier tell the controller when things go wrong, in which case we just need an api endpoint. And we also want the controller to be able to grab the most current status of the node at any point as we might want to perform a check before doing any state transitions. But if we need to guarantee that an attestation is recent, its not quite possible. This method is supposed to fill in that hole. All that is to say that I don't know how this would be done or if it is even needed, but the more I flesh out the spec the more I am leaning towards it being unnecessary.
So, when starting deployment? Does it correspond to track_machine?

I think with kernel parameters this entire process can be done. The idea behind track_machine() was that configuring the keylime agent might not be as simple as kernel parameters, but it appears I may have over-complicated things.

Is this proposing to add Keylime as an Openstack project under Bare Metal? If not, the spec should focus on the interface to Ironic and use cases for the interface, with Keylime referenced as one potential implementation. Ideally, we'd have multiple examples of services that could have a driver implemented in the SecurityInterface.
Since keylime is FOSS and vendor-neutral (?), I have no problems with it being a reference (and potentially only) implementation.

The idea of this spec is to put forth the generic security interface and a Keylime driver. Originally this spec was two specs but it was ultimately decided to merge the two as without the keylime details it wasn't obvious why a security interface would even be useful.

I don't think this addresses all potential alternatives. In fact, I built a similar framework where a machine with invalid firmware was removed from inventory via cleaning steps that validated the firmware and failed cleaning if it was invalid.

I'd like more explanation here as to why our existing, generic idea of "steps" (clean steps / deploy steps) cannot satisfy this use case.

Well this allows us to perform all of these steps at any moment, instead of along some state transition. With Keylime we can monitor booting and control the exact commands that a node is used for using the whitelists. Otherwise, what happens in between provisioning and cleaning is unknown. This is important for hardware leasing, where we an owner doesn't know who the hardware is being leased to and wants to more tightly monitor everything and make sure nothing which adheres from expectations occurs.

Also, if we did things at clean time, wouldnt some sort of attestation service be needed anyways? A driver with an interface which executes special steps at certain transitions seems more modular than building these actions into existing cleaning routines.
What exactly does it involve? How is it different from validate_security_status? When is it called?

The idea is that this attest call would be called at points along the state machine and tell the agent to attest itself. The validate_security_status call would just be a call to go to the verifier and get a status and act on it. It may end up being that both of these calls are used at the same point along the state machine, but the validate_security_status call may end up being made periodically while in a certain state.

Is there any other place in our code where we something designed to interact with IPA, but does not exist in DeployInterface? This seems like a weird merging of concerns and IMO is more evidence that this case could be handled by our existing "steps" model.
Does this initial registration have anything to do with ironic? If yes, please expand on what it involves.
There shouldnt be any work for this on ironic's end
If the initial registration for Keylime doesn't involve Ironic, it probably shouldn't be mentioned here.
Validation = the standard validate() call, not validate_security_status? Maybe we should have added validate explicitly just for clarity..
yeah this would be the standard validate() call.
Does the keylime agent need any information to identify the node? If yes, we need a way to pass it before the first heartbeat.
yeah. We have been looking into putting some of this information, mainly allowlists and  verifier_address (the agent and controller need this), through building it into the image.

specs/rocky/approved/glance/policy-refac.message:
If a user can't  update *any* image properties, he can't update the image location of cause IMO. If a user can update the image properties, maybe he is refused to  update the image location. So the policy can be defined like:

"image_update": ""
"image_update:location": "role:admin"

The the code can be like:

def update(context, image):
    policy.enforce("image_update",context,...)
    if image.get("location"):
        policy.enforce("image_update:location", context,....)
Personally I think the only user who ever needs to remove locations is admin. When the image is deleted the deletion of location should be internal matter to Glance and not subject to policy.

This is a good suggestion for how to arrange these in a logical way.  It would also work for other properties, like maybe:

  old   ->   new
  set_image_location -> modify_image:locations
  publicize_image  -> modify_image:visibility:public
  communitize_image  -> modify_image:visibility:community

Question: how do we deal with delete_image_location ?

The location policy can be different for such case, for example:

For ``GET /v2/images/{image_id}/file``, the policy can be "image_download: location": "role:admin or role:service"
For ``GET /v2/images/{image_id}`, the policy can be "image_get:location": "role:admin"

My thought was that we wouldn't need a policy on location for the GET v2/images/{id}/file since it's already covered by image_download (the location doesn't appear in the response).

I like your idea of image_get:locations , it would be clear what it applies to, and would be extensible to other "sensitive" image properties.  We could replace the show_image_url config option with a 'image_get:direct_url' policy.
One more update coming? Or to be updated after spec is merged and more details are worked out in code?
I was hoping to have more info here before the spec is merged.  I may need a spec freeze exception.  (I thought someone else was going to pick this up.)

I think we can all agree that this work needs to happen and will not be done in Rocky and we do have the feature branch to get the work started. Let's not worry about merging this spec for Rocky either. We can always experiment in the feature branch and see what approach could work while working on the spec.
One more thing we should consider is the backward compatibility between the new policy structure and the old ones

If we are just patching a resource and keeping the same name, we can't use this same methodology for multiple tests against the same cluster, as the name will already be taken. I think we should either:

1) move these overrides directly into the sample SipCluster, and deploy this CR in it's own script, and then we can other other scripts to test individual services and/or scheduling of this single SipCluster CR.
2) Or if we want better isolation we could have separate test SipCluster CRs for each service or even multiple per service, but these should all have their own CR name and inherit from a SipCluster CR which has no services enabled, just scheduling specs, which we could use to test the scheduling independently as well.

I would think we would eventually want 2) but 1) could be at least a good starting place.

We can do this in a separate patchset if easier though.

source: https://cert-manager.io/docs/reference/api-docs/#cert-manager.io/v1alpha2.Certificate

I wonder if it may be worth it to make some changes here to clarify what's actually happening and also I see some potential for re-use:

- Rename 'is_cert_secret_ready' to something like 'wait_cert_secret_ready'
- Expose the timeout_seconds as a named parameter (with default) to allow overriding the timeout
- Rather than a boolean, you could directly return the secret in this call, or None if it times out. The secret contents should be available directly in the notification from the watch, so this would both save an API call as well as making it more clear that there's a wait in the call where you're checking if the secret is ready.
Agreed with the first two, the third one should be good if it's possible, will run some tests first to check and if it's good apply this modification
I am not going to block the review over this, but I am used to the coding convention where a method that starts with 'is_'  would typically return a boolean rather than an object/or None
You're right guys, I can change this on a new patchset
agree .. something like get_cert_secret() would be more appropriate

manila_ui/dashboards/admin/shares/forms..message: Please, keep it as tuple as it was. "tuple init" is much faster than "list init". Same in all other similar places.
Now it is possible to set values twice and the ones that are in separate inputs can be easily overriden. Need to add here check for absence of duplication.

On the second thought snapshot_support and driver_handles_share_servers cannot be overriden just because they stay in data and if they are the same keys in set_dict, the values will be overriden by data in L#221. In other words the two separate fields have higher priority and it doesn't matter what we put in extra_specs field. However there's still a possibility to get an error while trying to unset snapshot_support and driver_handles_share_servers in this field and it definitely should be handled properly.
Good point, thank you. We should remove the duplicates here and add a corresponding help message.
